abstract.p: Personal Shopper column on sources and prices of dining chairs made from leather, rich woods, rattan and wicker; photos (M)

block.p: THE materials are the message here: leather, rich woods, rattan and wicker make these sleek dining chairs too appealing to hide under the table. Many are comfortable enough for reading or lounging between meals. And none of the basketwork chairs felt prickly, so hold the cushions.
1. Relax, an Italian chair by Studio Datta e Mosca, front, has a steel frame covered in leather. It comes in 16 colors and costs $917 (with arms, $1,033) at DDC, 181 Madison Avenue (34th Street).

THE materials are the message here: leather, rich woods, rattan and wicker make these sleek dining chairs too appealing to hide under the table. Many are comfortable enough for reading or lounging between meals. And none of the basketwork chairs felt prickly, so hold the cushions.
1. Relax, an Italian chair by Studio Datta e Mosca, front, has a steel frame covered in leather. It comes in 16 colors and costs $917 (with arms, $1,033) at DDC, 181 Madison Avenue (34th Street).

The Panama, designed by Antonio Citterio, is a padded chair with a removable cover -- in fabric, starting at $333, or made of white leather (shown) soft as a marshmallow, for $596; at B&B Italia, 150 East 58th Street, www.bebitalia.it or (800) 872-1697.

2. The Emmy Armchair, by Rick Shaver for Shaver/Melahn Studios, was inspired by supper-club chairs of the 1930's and 40's. Upholstered in leather with wood arms and legs, this ample chair is comfortable enough to be used for relaxing between meals; $2,150 (without arms, $1,795) at Blumenthal, 979 Third Avenue (59th Street). To the trade only.

3. The Pasqualina armchair, left, designed by Marina Grassi and Sergio Bianchi, is covered in leather in a number of colors including black, white, red, yellow, salmon and three tones of brown. The chair is comfortable but snug; $980 from Palazzetti, 515 Madison Avenue (53rd Street) or (888) 881-1199.
Sharon, an Italian chair by Ca'Nova, has a leather seat and back and comes in 16 colors and several choices of wood; $646 from DDC.
4. Split-rattan and wicker chairs, from left:
An Italian-made rattan armchair by Gervasoni is $821 (without arms, $672) at Homer, 939 Madison Avenue (74th Street).
A rattan side chair is a licensed reproduction of a 1935 design by Jean-Michel Frank; $1,000 at Pucci International, 44 West 18th Street.

The Manhattan bleached-wicker armchair with black lacquered wood legs is $149 (and if you must, a seat cushion in brushed cotton is $29.95) at Crate & Barrel, 650 Madison Avenue (59th Street); (800) 967-6696 or www.crateandbarrel.com.
A wicker dining chair with wood legs is $119 from Pottery Barn, www .potterybarn.com or (800) 922-5507.
The Iron Rope chandelier is $299 from the Pottery Barn catalog.
